title: Cryo-FIB Milling for Uni- and Multicellular Samples â€“ the Base for Cryo-Electron Tomography at Molecular Resolution
content: In recent years, cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) on lamellae, i.e. after thinning of plunge-frozen single cells or cell extracts by focused ion beam (FIB) milling, has provided amazing insights into the structural biology of large macromolecular complexes and their conformational states in situ [1]. The extension of such FIB-based cryo-ET studies to larger samples that include tissues and small organisms, however, was and is not straightforward. Although proof of concept has been demonstrated, those early approaches to access for example C. elegans have had limited applicability due to workflow complexity, duration, and most importantly, extremely low success rates [2]. In addition, although there are various protocols for the vitrification of such samples, vitrification is in most cases incomplete, making it necessary to refine and adapt them.
